events.title: Louisiana Purchase
events.description: The United States purchases Louisiana Territory.

events.title: Lewis and Clark Expeditions
events.description: Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark enter area that would become Idaho at Lemhi Pass.

events.title: Kullyspell House Erected
events.description: Kullyspell House, first non-native establishment in Northwest, is erected near Lake Pend Oreille.

events.title: Fort Henry Established
events.description: Fort Henry, first American fur post west of Rocky Mountains, established near St. Anthony.

events.title: Astorian Parties explore Idaho
events.description: Astorian parties under Wilson Price Hunt explore portions of the future Oregon Trail in Idaho.

events.title: Joint Occupation Treaty for Oregon Territory
events.description: U.S. &amp; Great Britain sign Joint Occupation Treaty for Oregon Territory.

events.title: Mackenzie Rendezvous with Native Americans
events.description: Donald Mackenzie holds a rendezvous with Native Americans on the Boise River. Adams-Onis treaty between Spain and the United States establishes Idaho's future southern border on the 42nd Parallel. Mackenzie attempts to set up a post on the Boise River.

events.title: Mackenzie Negotiates Peace Treaty with Shoshone
events.description: Mackenzie negotiates a peace treaty with the Shoshone on Little Lost River and explores most of what would become Goodale's Cutoff.

events.title: Hudson's Bay and NW Company Merge
events.description: Hudson's Bay Company and North West Company merge.

events.title: Rocky Mountain Fur Company Organized
events.description: William Ashley organizes the Rocky Mountain Fur Company, which institutes the practice of annual rendezvous.

events.title: Bonneville's Wagon Train Across South Pass
events.description: Captain B.L.E. Bonneville takes a wagon train across South Pass to Green River.

events.title: Caravan Travels to Wind River
events.description: A trapper's wheeled caravan travels over part of the Oregon Trail west of Casper to the Wind River rendezvous.

events.title: Forts Laramie, Boise, and Hall are established.
events.description: Forts Laramie, Boise, and Hall are established.

events.title: Spaulding Establishes Mission near Lapwai
events.description: Henry H. Spalding establishes a mission near Lapwai, where he prints the Northwest's first book, establishes Idaho's first school, develops Idaho's first irrigation system, and grows the state's first potatoes. Narcissa Whitman and Eliza Spalding are the first white women to cross the continental divide (South Pass).

events.title: First Oregon Trail wagons cross Idaho.
events.description: First Oregon Trail wagons cross Idaho.

events.title: Boundary Dispute With England Settled
events.description: Treaty settles the Oregon boundary dispute with England.

events.title: Heavy Emigration
events.description: Over 20,000 emigrants who join the gold rush come through southeastern Idaho on the California Trail. Heavy traffic continues on the trail for many years.

events.title: Military Post Established
events.description: U.S. Military post, Cantonment Loring, is established near Fort Hall.

events.title: Gold Discovered
events.description: French Canadians discover gold on the Pend Oreille River.

events.title: Washington Territory is Created.
events.description: Washington Territory is created.

events.title: Fort Lemhi Established
events.description: Salmon River mission (Fort Lemhi) is established by Mormon missionaries, to be abandoned in 1858.

events.title: Oregon Becomes a State
events.description: Oregon is admitted as a state.

events.title: First Town in Idaho Established
events.description: Franklin, first town in Idaho, is established.

events.title: Mining Strike
events.description: Major mining strikes occur near Pierce, Florence, Idaho City, and Silver City.

events.title: Idaho's First Newspaper
events.description: On August 2, 1862, the Golden Age newspaper released its inaugural issue in Lewiston, Washington Territory. The Age thus has the honor of being the first newspaper published in what would become, seven months later, Idaho Territory. The publisher was a man named A. S. Gould, about whom we know very little.

events.title: Idaho Becomes a Territory
events.description: Idaho becomes a territory on March 4 with Lewiston as its capital. The Bear River Massacre, the West's largest slaughter of Indians, is fought near present-day Preston.

events.title: Capital Moves to Boise
events.description: Territorial Legislature approves moving capital to Boise.

events.title: Telegraph Service Reaches Idaho
events.description: Telegraph service reaches Idaho.

events.title: Snake Indian War
events.description: Snake Indian War.

events.title: Idaho's First Labor Union
events.description: Owyhee Miners' League in Owyhee County organizes as state's first labor union.

events.title: Population 17,804
events.description: Idaho population 17,804.

events.title: Assay Office and Idaho Prison
events.description: U.S. Assay office and Idaho prison are completed.

events.title: Railroad Comes to Idaho
events.description: Railroad service reaches Idaho at Franklin.

events.title: Nez Perce War
events.description: Nez Perce Indian War.

events.title: Bannock War
events.description: Bannock Indian War.

events.title: Sheepeater Indian Campaign
events.description: Sheepeater Indian campaign.

events.title: Population 32,610
events.description: Idaho population 32,610. Boise and Lewiston independent school districts are created.

events.title: Historical Society of Idaho Forms
events.description: Historical Society of Idaho Pioneers forms to collect and preserve a reliable history of the early settlement of the territory.

events.title: First Electric Light
events.description: State's first electric light is turned on at the Philadelphia Smelter near Ketchum.

events.title: Commercial Telephone
events.description: Commercial telephone service in Idaho begins at Hailey.

events.title: Silver Discovered
events.description: Silver is discovered in the Coeur d'Alene mining district, which eventually becomes nation's richest.

events.title: Completion of Oregon Short Line
events.description: Completion of the Oregon Short Line.

events.title: University of Idaho Established
events.description: Constitutional Convention convenes on July 4, with the constitution ratified by the people on November 5. Territorial Legislature establishes the University of Idaho.

events.title: Idaho Becomes a State
events.description: Idaho population 88,548. Idaho becomes 43rd state on July 3.

events.title: First Classes Held at College of Idaho
events.description: First classes are held at the College of Idaho, in Caldwell.

events.title: Butch Cassidy Robs Bank
events.description: Butch Cassidy robs the bank in Montpelier.

events.title: Population, 161,722
events.description: Idaho population 161,722.

events.title: Completion of Milner Dam
events.description: Completion of Milner Dam brings irrigation to the south side of the Snake River.

events.title: Governor Assassinated
events.description: Former Governor Frank Steunenberg is assassinated.

events.title: Lawgest Sawmill in US Opens
events.description: Largest sawmill in the United States opens at Potlatch.

events.title: Borah Elected to Senate
events.description: William E. Borah is elected to the U.S. Senate, where he serves 33 years.

events.title: Walter 'Big Train' Johnson signs with the Wash. Senators.
Population 325,594
events.description: Idaho population 325,594.

events.title: The Big Burn: Devastating Forest Fires
events.description: Forest fires consume one-sixth of north Idaho's forests.

events.title: First Jewish Governor in US
events.description: Moses Alexander is first elected Jewish governor in United States.

events.title: State Board of Education Established
events.description: State Board of Education is established.

events.title: Battleship Idaho Launched
events.description: Battleship Idaho  is launched.

events.title: Father of Television
events.description: Philo Farnsworth, 15-year-old student and inventor from Rigby, develops concepts that lead to invention of television and earn him the name 'Father of Television'.

events.title: First Radio Station
events.description: Idaho's first radio station, KFAU, at Boise High School, goes on the air in 1922.

events.title: Craters of the Moon established
events.description: Craters of the Moon National Monument is established.

events.title: First Commercial Airmail Service in US
events.description: First commercial airmail service in the U.S. begins in Boise.

events.title: Population 445,032
events.description: Idaho population 445,032.

events.title: Leading Silver Producer in US
events.description: Idaho becomes nation's leading silver producer.

events.title: Sun Valley Established
events.description: Sun Valley resort is established by the Union Pacific Railroad. World's first ski chair lift opens at Sun Valley.

events.title: Albertsons Opens
events.description: Joe Albertson opens his first supermarket in Boise.

events.title: Population 524,873
events.description: Idaho population 524,873.

events.title: Simplot Opens
events.description: J.R. Simplot begins potato dehydration operations in Caldwell.

events.title: Japanese American Internment
events.description: Japanese-Americans are placed in internment camp near Eden.

events.title: National Reactor Testing Station Established
events.description: National Reactor Testing Station (NRTS) is established.

events.title: Population 588,637
events.description: Idaho population 588,637.

events.title: Nuclear Fission to Produce Energy
events.description: NRTS becomes site of the worlds' first use of nuclear fission to produce electricity. Experimental Breeder Reactor No. 1 is later designated a National Landmark.

events.title: Television Comes to Idaho
events.description: Television comes to Idaho with KIDO-TV in Boise.

events.title: Population 667,191
events.description: Idaho population 667,191.

events.title: Ernest Hemingway Dies
events.description: Ernest Hemingway dies in Ketchum.

events.title: 3% Sales Tax
events.description: Voters uphold 3% state sales tax.

events.title: Population 713,015
events.description: Idaho population 713,015.

events.title: Sunshine Mine Fire
events.description: Fire at the Sunshine Mine in Kellogg takes 91 lives.

events.title: Port of Lewiston Opens
events.description: Port of Lewiston opens Idaho to ocean-going shipping.

events.title: Teton Dam Collapse
events.description: Teton Dam collapses, killing 11 and forcing thousands to flee their homes.

events.title: Governor Appointed Secretary of Interior
events.description: Governor Cecil D. Andrus is appointed Secretary of the Interior.

events.title: Property Tax Restrictions
events.description: Voters approve tax limitation placing severe restrictions on the use of the property tax.

events.title: Senator Appointed Chairman Senate Foreign Relations Committee
events.description: Senator Frank Church becomes chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

events.title: Population 944,038
events.description: Idaho population 944,038.

events.title: Mount St. Helens erupts
events.description: Eruption of Mt. St. Helens in Washington leaves north Idaho covered with a layer of volcanic ash.

events.title: Senator Appointed Chairman Energy and Natural Resources Committee
events.description: Senator James McClure becomes chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee in the 97th - 99th Congresses.

events.title: Challis Earthquake
events.description: An earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale kills two Challis children and caused millions of dollars of damage.

events.title: Harmon Killebrew Inducted to Baseball Hall of Fame
events.description: Harmon Killebrew of Payette inducted into Baseball Hall of Fame.

events.title: Idaho Finalists in NASA Teacher in Space Program
events.description: David Marquart (Boise) and Barbara Morgan (McCall) are among 10 finalists out of 11,000 applicants in the NASA Teacher in Space program. Barbara Morgan later becomes Teacher in Space backup to Christa McAuliffe, and Teacher in Space designee in 1986, and later the first education mission specialist.

events.title: Population 1,006,749
events.description: Idaho population 1,006,749.

events.title: Statehood Centennial
events.description: Idaho celebrates Statehood Centennial - July 3.

events.title: First Woman Appointed to Idaho Supreme Court
events.description: Linda Copple Trout becomes the first woman appointed to the Idaho Supreme Court.

events.title: Third Fastest Population Growth in Nation
events.description: Idaho ranks third nationwide in percentage population growth after the state adds another 33,000 residents.

events.title: 1st American to Win World Cup Downhill
events.description: Picabo Street becomes first American to win World Cup downhill title

events.title: Larry Craig in the Senate (Click to drill down)
events.description: Larry Edwin Craig (born July 20, 1945) is a former Republican politician from the U.S. state of Idaho. He served eighteen years in the U.S. Senate (1991–2009), preceded by ten years in the U.S. House, representing Idaho's first district (1981–91). His 28 years in the Congress rank as the second-longest in Idaho history, trailing only William Borah, who served over 32 years in the Senate. In addition to serving in Congress, Craig has been a member of the Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association since 1983. Craig has also been selected for induction into the Idaho Hall of Fame. Although he was selected in March 2007, the announcement was made in October 2007.

events.title: Boise State wins the Fiesta Bowl
events.description:
The 2007 Tostitos Fiesta Bowl was a college football bowl game played as part of the 2006–2007 Bowl Championship Series (BCS) of the 2006 NCAA Division I FBS football season. Played annually since 1971, originally at Sun Devil Stadium on the campus of Arizona State University in Tempe, Arizona through 2006, the game was played on January 1, 2007, at the game's new home field, the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Arizona, and pitted the Big 12 champion #8 Oklahoma Sooners against the WAC champion #9 Boise State Broncos. The contest was televised on Fox. With this broadcast, the Fiesta Bowl became the first bowl game to air on all the 'big four' television networks (ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC) - the Orange Bowl became the second, the following night.

Oklahoma was the designated home team and was favored by 7½ points, but the Broncos won in overtime, 43–42. Oklahoma wore their red home jerseys, while Boise State wore their road white jerseys. Both Boise, Idaho and Norman, Oklahoma are about 15 hour trips from the bowl site.

The game featured a series of 'fantastic finishes' – Oklahoma scoring 25 unanswered points to take its first lead with just over one minute remaining in the game, the teams scoring 22 points in the final 1:26 of regulation and 15 points in overtime, culminating with Boise State completing three do-or-die trick plays (the first of which was called with 17 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter) to win the game.
